content.definition: A structured surveillance program following endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) to detect endoleaks, graft migration, component separation, aneurysm sac expansion, and other complications that may lead to late aneurysm rupture. Surveillance is lifelong after EVAR.

need_for_surveillance: Endoleaks can develop early or late
Graft migration occurs in 2-5% of patients
Sac expansion despite successful seal can occur
Type II endoleaks may become clinically significant
rationale.comparison_to_open: Open repair typically does not require lifelong surveillance

low_risk_protocol.imaging: May transition to duplex ultrasound for annual surveillance

limitations: Cannot detect endoleak or sac size

findings_requiring_intervention: Type II endoleak with sac expansion >5 mm

endoleak_surveillance.type_II: Observe if sac stable; treat if expanding

importance_of_compliance: Late rupture deaths occur in surveillance dropouts

learning_objectives: Understand when to use CTA vs ultrasound
clinical_pearls: EVAR surveillance is LIFELONG - unlike open repair
CTA at 1, 6, and 12 months; then annual
Stable patients may transition to duplex after 1 year
Type I and III endoleaks = URGENT intervention
Type II endoleak: treat only if sac expanding >5 mm
Non-compliance is major issue - educate patients
